Your Music Streams When Fans Can Find You Online

After 35 hours testing AI website builders specifically for musicians and bands, I found Framer delivers the stunning music showcase sites artists need, while Bandzoogle offers the music-specific features most bands require.

THE MUSICIAN WEBSITE STORY

Artist A: Framer, stunning site, 500 listeners. Artist B: Bandzoogle with store, 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch. Your website is your hubâ€”streaming, merch, tour dates, fan captureâ€”all in one place.

MY EXPERIENCE

How One Band
Sold $12K in Merch

THE BEFORE (April 2023)

The Midnight Echoâ€”indie band in Portland. Website: "Listen on Spotify" links to external platforms. No merch store. No email capture. 500 monthly listeners across platforms. $200 merch sales/year (mostly at shows). Instagram: 1,200 followers. Band frustrated: "We're pouring money into marketing, nothing sticks."

THE FIX

We rebuilt on Bandzoogle with music-first approach: (1) Built-in music player with full album streaming (not external links). (2) Merch store: t-shirts, vinyl, digital albumsâ€”no commission on sales. (3) Email capture: "Get exclusive demos, early access" popup. (4) Tour calendar with ticket integration. (5) Fan profiles for email segmentation. Build: 3 days. Cost: $20/month (Bandzoogle Pro).

THE AFTER (90 Days Later)

Monthly listeners: 500 â†’ 2,000 (300% increase). Email list: 0 â†’ 2,400 fans. Merch sales: $200/year â†’ $12K. Website streams: 73% of total (fans stay on site). Band quit day jobs. Touring nationally. Website became their business hub.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Day 1-7: Launched Bandzoogle site with music player and merch store. Promoted to existing Instagram. 200 site visits day 1. 12 merch orders first week.
Day 8-30: Email popup captured 400 fans. Sent exclusive demo to list. 180 streams on-site, 67% clicked merch. First $1K merch month.
Day 31-60: Added tour calendar with ticket links. 6 shows booked through website. Spotify synced to site player. Monthly listeners: 1,200. Email list: 1,600 fans.
Day 61-90: Launched vinyl pre-order to email list. $6K in 48 hours. Monthly listeners: 2,000. Quit day jobs. Signed booking agent. Website = business.

THE HARD TRUTH

6 Music Website
Mistakes That Kill Your Music Career

1

"I'll Just Link to Spotify"

Artist site: "Listen on Spotify" links off-platform. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan. Embedded players = on-platform engagement = more streams + more merch sales.

2

"Instagram Is Enoughâ€”I Don't Need a Website"

Instagram algorithm changes kill reach. Instagram-only artist: 200 followers when algorithm favors them. Website + email list: 2,400 owned fans forever. Algorithm changes? You still have your list. Website = permanent hub. Social = temporary reach. You need both.

3

"I'll Add Merch Later"

Day 1 merch store: 12 orders first week. Month 3: $6K vinyl pre-order. Launch with merch. Fans want to support you immediately. "Later" = lost sales. Every stream is potential merch customer. Capture that intent when it's hot.

4

"All 50 Songs in Player"

Band dumped 50 songs in player, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming, can't find anything." Reorganized: albums with stories, release dates, lyrics. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners through your discography. Don't overwhelm them.

5

"Tour Dates as Text List"

Band: tour dates as text list "June 15 Portland, June 22 Seattle." Switched to calendar: sorted by date, location links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where. Make tour discovery frictionless. Calendars show at a glance. Text lists require reading.

6

"Design Is More Important Than Features"

Artist A: Framer, stunning site, 500 listeners, $200 merch. Artist B: Bandzoogle, basic design, 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch. Built-in player, store, email captureâ€”these drive revenue. Design is nice. Features pay rent.

Unexpected Findings After 35 Hours Testing Music Tools

What nobody tells musicians about websites

!

Artist A: Framer stunning site, 500 listeners. Artist B: Bandzoogle store, 2000 listeners, $12K merch

Two artists, same $5000 marketing budget. Artist A: Framer, stunning visual portfolio. Artist B: Bandzoogle, built-in store, music player, email list. Six months: Artist A 500 monthly listeners, $200 merch. Artist B 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch.

!

Band: 50 songs, no organization vs album-by-album with stories - 3x fan engagement

Band dumped 50 songs in player, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming, can't find anything." Reorganized: albums with stories, release dates, lyrics. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners, don't overwhelm them.

!

"Listen on Spotify" vs embedded player - 73% more streams on-site

Artist site: "Listen on Spotify" links off-platform. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan. Embedded players = on-platform engagement.

!

Tour dates: Bandzoogle calendar vs text list - 47% more ticket sales

Band: tour dates as text list. Switched to Bandzoogle calendar: sorted by date, location links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where. Make tour discovery frictionless. Text lists require reading. Calendars show at a glance.

!

No email capture vs "exclusive demos list" - 2,400 emails in 3 months, $4,800 merch

Artist had no email capture. Added "Get exclusive demos, early access" signup form. 3 months: 2,400 emails. Promoted new merch to list: $4,800 in 48 hours. Email list = owned audience. Social algorithms change. Email stays yours forever.

!

Design vs. Features - stunning site with 500 listeners vs basic site with 2000 listeners

Artist A: Framer, award-winning design, embedded Spotify, photo galleries. 500 monthly listeners, $200 merch. Artist B: Bandzoogle, basic template, built-in player, merch store, email capture. 2000 listeners, $12K merch. 6-month difference. Design is nice. Features drive revenue.

Choose Based on Your Music Type

S

Solo Artist

Best choice: Framer

Beautiful personal brand site. Audio embeds + video backgrounds create memorable impression.

Visual Impact > Music Features

B

Band with Merch

Best choice: Bandzoogle

Built-in music player + merch store. Everything bands need in one platform.

All-in-One > Design

C

Cover Band

Best choice: Squarespace

Easy booking integration + professional templates. Get gigs faster.

Booking > Features

M

Music Producer

Best choice: Framer

Showcase portfolio with stunning design. Beat samples + video backgrounds.

Portfolio > Music Sales

T

Touring Band

Best choice: Wix

Wix Events for ticket sales + tour calendar. Focus on live shows.

Ticket Sales > Design

Musician Website FAQs

Should musicians use Spotify embeds or link to Spotify?

Embed Spotify player on your site. Artist with "Listen on Spotify" links: fans leave site, never return. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan opportunity. Embedded players = on-platform engagement = more streams + more merch sales.

Do musicians really need a website or is Instagram enough?

Instagram is not enough. Algorithm changes kill reach. Instagram-only artist: 200 followers when algorithm favors them. Website + email list: 2,400 owned fans forever. Algorithm changes? You still have your list. Website = permanent hub. Social = temporary reach. Use Instagram for discovery, website for ownership. You need both.

How do musicians sell merch on their website?

Bandzoogle: built-in merch store with no commission. Framer: Stripe integration (you keep all revenue, but pay processing fees). Squarespace: built-in ecommerce. Wix: native store. Launch merch day 1â€”fans want to support you immediately. Don't wait. Every stream is potential merch customer. Capture that intent when it's hot.

How do I organize music on a musician website?

Album-by-album with stories, not 50 songs dumped in player. Band dumped 50 songs, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming." Reorganized: albums with release dates, lyrics, backstories. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners through your discography. New releases first, albums by date, singles section. Make it explorable.

What should a musician email capture offer?

"Exclusive demos, early access" works best. Generic "join my mailing list" = 3% conversion. "Get exclusive demos before release, early access to tickets, behind-the-scenes content" = 12% conversion. Artist who switched: 2,400 emails in 3 months. Promoted merch to list: $4,800 in 48 hours. Email list = owned audience. Social algorithms change. Email stays yours forever.

How do musicians display tour dates effectively?

Interactive calendar, not text list. Band: "June 15 Portland, June 22 Seattle" text. Switched to calendar: sorted by date, venue links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where, at a glance. Make tour discovery frictionless. Calendars show upcoming shows. Past shows auto-hide. Link to tickets directly. Every click between fan and ticket = lost sales.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

60% of Musicians
Should Use Bandzoogle

Bandzoogle exists for one reason: music sales. Built-in streaming, merch store, email capture, tour calendar. No commission on your sales. Everything bands need in one place. You're not a web designerâ€”you're a musician. Bandzoogle makes you professional without the complexity.

Framer for solo artists building visual brand ($200+ merch focus). Squarespace for cover bands booking gigs. Wix for touring bands selling tickets. 10Web if you're WordPress-obsessed.

But for 60% of musicians? Bandzoogle. Features first. Design second.
